user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtMem2BinFileCmp:
```c
bool UtMem2BinFileCmp(const void *Memory, const char *Filename)
{
    FILE *       fp;
    const uint8 *MemByte = Memory;
    int          FileByte;
    bool         Success;
    uint32       i;

    Success = true;
    if ((fp = fopen(Filename, "r")))
    {
        for (i = 0; (FileByte = fgetc(fp)) != EOF; i++)
        {
            if (MemByte[i] != FileByte)
            {
                Success = false;
                printf("UtMem2BinFileCmp: Miscompare in file: %s, byte offset: %lu, expected: %u, found: %u\n",
                       Filename, (unsigned long)i, (unsigned int)MemByte[i], (unsigned int)FileByte);
                break;
            }
        }
        fclose(fp);
    }
    else
    {
        Success = false;
        printf("UtMem2BinFileCmp: Error Opening File: %s, %s\n", Filename, strerror(errno));
        UtAssert_True(false, "UtMem2BinFileCmp: Error Opening File");
    }

    return Success;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtMem2BinFileCmp:
#define UtAssert_True(Expression, __VA_ARGS__) UtAssertEx(Expression,UtAssert_GetContext(),__FILE__,__LINE__,__VA_ARGS__)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No controlling expressions in the provided function are invariant. The if condition if ((fp = fopen(Filename, "r"))) evaluates the dynamic result of fopen and is not constant. The for loop for (i = 0; (FileByte = fgetc(fp)) != EOF; i++) uses the return value of fgetc(fp) as its controlling expression and is therefore dynamic (not invariant). The UtAssert_True(false, ...) call is an argument containing a constant but is not itself a controlling expression (it is a function/macro call), so it does not violate Rule 14.3. There are no do-while loops or other conditional constructs with constant controlling expressions in this code. Therefore no code fragments require investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3.
